intro: Blakea gerardoana, commonly known as the Ecuadorian Blakea, is a species of flowering plant in the family Malvaceae. It is native to the cloud forests of western Ecuador and is characterized by its striking, showy flowers. The plant typically grows as an epiphyte, attaching itself to trees in its natural habitat. Its leaves are ovate to elliptic in shape, with a smooth surface and a pointed tip. The flowers are usually pink or red, with five petals and prominent stamens, making it a visually distinctive species.
